The game is turn based and each player takes on the role of the Game Master, as well as the role of the Active Player, respectively. During your turn you draw treasure cards, equip yourself with items, use trinkets or provisions and prepare for a new day of adventure. After that you enter the Travel Phase in which you will face a random encounter, drawn by the current Game Master. Here you can meet creatures to fight, locations to explore, or trigger special global Events. Your choices and die rolls determine the outcome of each encounter and they may be different each time. Resolving encounter cards will allow you to advance on the board. During fights you may play combat spells or use your unique Hero element abilities.

If you want to know more details about the gameplay you can download the rulebook beta version below.

				
				
					The Goal:You Hero has to reach the peak of the mountain, meaning the final field on the board, first. Here you must defeat the boss, belonging to one of the three enemy factions. The Hero who manages to defeat the boss first wins the game.


				
				
					The Game Components:
    There are 8 different playable Hero Cards for you to choose from! Each with their own strengths and weaknesses, all of them embarking on this journey for their own reasons and goals.



    The game also contains 3 Boss Cards. These introduce the menacing creatures awaiting you on top of the Cursed Mountain. They are the last obstacle between you and your victory. One boss for each Faction. 



    Additionally, there are 75 different and unique Treasure Cards. Items, trinkets, provisions and spells are the usable treasures. These cards are used to boost your stats, heal you or give you other powerful bonuses. Armor and weapons can be equipped to strengthen your Heroes attack and resistance. 



    There are 75 different and unique Encounter Cards for your Heroes to face. They include creatures, locations and meetings, everything you can come across on your journey. The creatures belong to one of 3 factions, each with their own special creature types. Most encounters require your choices on how to proceed. There is no wrong or right with your choices, each one can lead to a positive or negative outcome.



    The game also includes 15 different Event Cards. They feature situations you and the other Heroes have to face while they travel. Events are only triggered when you land on certain fields on your path. They often have consequences that affect many Heroes at once.


—description from the publisher

Name: Summon The JSON: JavaScript Deck
Description:
Summon The JSON: JavaScript is a fantasy-themed printed card-game deck. Up to four casual gamers can combine cards to strategically win the game. Each game takes about fifteen minutes what makes the game perfect for short breaks, while everyone will likely want to play it again and again!

STJ: JavaScript rules can be explained in three minutes so that everyone can start to play right away. It is a great way to have some quality time with friends and colleagues or connect and chat with newly met people.

Tuck box packed 65-card breathtakingly illustrated deck is embossed with a linen texture and covered by durable UV coating making it a premium quality product.

It comes with a short booklet explaining game rules, and also describes two memorization methods. Aside from a game, each card represents a programming function in JavaScript you can learn. You don't need to code to enjoy the game, while you can learn to code if you want to.

—description from the publisher

Name: Grim(m) World: First Steps
Description:
Once upon a time, a nobody went out into the wide fairy tale world to escape from his dreary everyday life and become somebody. Be that nobody and become a somebody.

Grim(m) World is a solo open-world card game set in the fairy tale world of the Brothers Grimm. Here you play an ordinary person who sets out to experience adventure. The player is not told how his journey should look like. He is free to decide where he goes and what he wants to do. Maybe he wants to accumulate trade and wealth? Or does he want to make a name for himself as a bounty hunter? Maybe he also wants to save Little Red Riding Hood from the bad wolf or even help the wolf hunting Little Red Riding Hood. The world reacts and changes based on your decisions. Are you ready for this adventure?

Grim(m) World is based on the OWCS (Open World Card System). The OWCS is a system to simulate an Open World as a card game. An encounter deck with multi-use cards serves as a random encounter, as an object deck, it triggers quests, dice rolls are simulated, it defines prices for trading and it simulates the time in the game world. An additional quest deck simulates the living world in the game. Depending on the time in the game, new missions appear or disappear, events happen or the world changes. Additionally, your own character can be leveled up and becomes stronger and stronger as the game progresses. The battles in the game are fought on a grid field laid out with cards. Your hand cards serve as life points and determine the character's possible actions during a fight. The opponents are controlled by a simple card-based AI.

—description from the designer

Name: Top 10!
Description: Be the first to get rid of your cards. Each card has a certain number of animals which must be added to arrive at 10. A game of cards for beginners in calculation.

Name: Westward Ho!
Description:
In Westward Ho! Two to six players take the role of powerbrokers building the American west, from 1848 through 1881.

In each turn players take actions to move pioneers into new territories, build railroads, rake off profits from new industries, and other actions.

There’s plenty of action, with the US cavalry, Indians, militia, and famous outlaws all involved.

The map shows the US divided into the historic territories of the era.

Cards represent famous personalities, critical commercial firms (such as Wells Fargo and the Union Pacific) and historic events.

The player who accumulates the most wealth by the end of the game wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Miniland
Description:
To play this entertaining, gaily coloured game, you need six children, but a smaller number is no objection. Each player gets one peg. The first player rolls the coloured dice and follows up by placing his peg in the first section having the same colour as the top of the coloured dice. When it is their turn to play, the other players proceed likewise.
Winner is the player who first reaches the end of the course. To do so, it is necessary for the player that his peg ends up on the last blue section, near the flower garden, or that he throws a colour which would have gotten him past that blue section if the course had been a longer one.

—user summary
